Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Expectation2: Provide clients with clear and accurate legal advice
Situation2: The client’s case grows more complex and requires detailed guidance
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, the sales dashboard showing my numbers climbing higher than I’d ever managed before. As a telemarketer, I was expected to keep this momentum, to push harder, to meet and exceed the targets my manager set. Every call was a chance to close another deal, and this week, I was on fire. But as an advocate, my phone buzzed with messages from a client whose case was spiraling into complexity. She needed more than a quick answer—she needed careful, accurate legal advice, the kind that took time and focus. My manager’s emails reminded me to keep dialing, to not let up, while my client’s anxious voice on the other end of the line pleaded for clarity and reassurance. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the thrill of smashing my sales quota and the responsibility to guide someone through a legal maze. My hands hovered over the phone, my mind racing with the demands of both worlds, knowing I couldn’t give my best to both at the same time.
